Management System Summary
The management system oversees the implementation of the RMP elements in order to manage the risk of a chemical release at this facility. Pursuant to Title 19 CCR Section 5050.6, a program management system has been established to oversee the implementation of the RMP elements.  Management system components for this facility include:
Identification of the qualified person/position with responsibility for coordinating the RMP
Organizational chart showing the positions with tasks involving the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system
Roles and responsibilities of positions at the facility
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
No action items were identified during the Hazard Review what-if scenarios analysis. Ormond Beach enforces continuous improvements to safety and health and tracks training to ensure commitment to safe working practices and the protection of the employees and the environment. Ormond Beach will work closely with the CUPA to continue to ensure that all requirements are addressed.

The basic concept of Ormond Beachs emergency procedures is to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies. The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.
Ormond Beachs emergency procedures serve as a guide for emergency control staff, company personnel, emergency assistance groups, and law enforcement agencies that may be called upon to participate in controlling an emergency within the facility and surrounding areas. These procedures include employee notification of emergencies and evacuation procedures for all emergency situations.  
In December 2021, EPA updated Chapter 8 of the General Risk Management Program Guidance to reflect the new emergency response coordination provision (40 CFR 68.93), which required compliance beginning September 21, 2018. The owner or operator of a stationary source shall coordinate response needs with local emergency planning and response organizations to determine how the stationary source is addressed in the community emergency response plan and to ensure that local response organizations are aware of the regulated substances at the stationary source, their quantities, the risks presented by covered processes, and the resources and capabilities at the stationary source to respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance. Ormond Beach coordinates with the CUPA via Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) reporting via the California Environmental Reporting System (CERS) and other CUPA required RMP update procedures.
Pursuant to CUPA requirements (per 40 CFR Part 68.12 and 19 CCR Section 2745.8) emergency procedures are in place in the event of a release of a regulated substance (aqueous ammonia). Ormond Beach uses the proactive identification, evaluation, and mitigation for prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in process, procedures, or equipment. 
Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
In addition to implementation of the CalARP Prevention Program 2 elements, Ormond Beach has implemented specific safety features for the prevention, detection, and control of releases of regulated (and other) substances at the facility. The following are some of the control and detection equipment located in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials:
Pressure relief and safety valves
High-level alarms and shutoffs
Secondary tank containment (55,000 gallons) 
Emergency control stations (control room)
Ammonia gas detector system
Fail-safe and interlock process controls (automatic)
Emergency shutdown systems (ESD)
Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases from the aqueous ammonia storage and handling system at Ormond Beach in the past 5 years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage (40 CFR Part 68.42).

Compliance with the CalARP comprehensive program validates the integrity of the processes which handle flammable or toxic materials. The objective of the regulation is to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. To control these types of hazards, Ormond Beach has developed the necessary expertise, experience, judgment, and proactive initiative within their workforce to properly implement and maintain an effective prevention program. Through compliance with the regulations, standards, and with CUPA guidance, the Ormond Beach facility has implemented the requirements of the Prevention Program 2.
Prevention Program 2 Elements

Using this approach the following components were considered in the evaluation in accordance with Title 40 CFR Parts 68.48 through 68.60 (Subpart C) and Title 19 CCR Section 5070.6. V2O5 (trade name VNX) is the active SCR catalyst material. VNX is a solid deposited on a ceramic honeycomb material (less than 5 percent in matrix), the design of which promotes interaction with the exhaust gas stream within the SCR. As such, VNX remains within the SCR and is not released to the atmosphere. This substance, therefore, meets the definition of an article (Section 5050.3) and is therefore exempted from the requirements of the CalARP Program as per Section 5130.2(b)(3). VNX is not federally listed under 40 CFR 68, Appendix A.

The site is located in a light to heavy industrial zone. The main area covers approximately 53 acres and is bounded by Edison Drive to the north and by the Pacific Ocean to the south. A Ventura County Railway spur  terminates at the site. The local railway is shared with other industrial facilities in the area. A vicinity and location map is contained in Appendix A.
The Ormond Beach consists of two gas-fired boilers and associated steam-driven turbine units. The Unit 1 steam boiler is rated at 741 megawatts (MW) and the Unit 2 steam boiler is rated at 750 MW. The two auxiliary boilers used for starting the main units, are rated at 275 million British thermal units (MMBTU)/hour. Main Units 1 and 2 are each equipped with SCR for the control of oxides of nitrogen (NOX) emissions. Aqueous ammonia is also used in the station water treatment system for pH control, and in the demineralizer system for the regeneration of anion and cation exchange resins.
The regulated substance used at the facility above Californias threshold quantity (TQ) is aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide, 29 percent by weight). All other regulated substances onsite are in quantities below applicable TQs.
Selective Catalytic Reduction
Aqueous ammonia (CAS Number 1336-21-6), 29 percent concentration by weight, with a vapor pressure of 9.1 pounds per square inch gauge (psig) at 60 degrees Fahrenheit (°F), is used in the SCR system to control NOX emissions from the two steam boilers (Units 1 and 2) as Best Available Control Technology (BACT). The SCR system reduces NOX emissions by injecting ammonia into the boiler exhaust gas stream, upstream of a catalyst matrix. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is the policy of Ormond Beach to conduct its business operation in a manner that protects its employees, environment, property, and the general public from any harm that may occur as a result of its operation. To achieve this end, Ormond Beach: 
Strives to conduct its business so as to maintain compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.
Implements its emergency response policies to comply with the overall corporate policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and of minimizing risk to the public. The safety of emergency and non-affected personnel is the highest priority; therefore, all procedures must be implemented in the appropriate manner (i.e., safely executed rescue and medical activities). Protection of the environment is also a high priority. Once the issues of life, safety, and the environment are addressed, the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery may be considered.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Parts 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health and Safety Code (HSC) Section 25531 through Section 25543.3, this Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.
The scope of this RMP is based on the guidance of the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA), the City of Oxnard Fire Department, to ensure that all contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements. With input from the CUPA, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) ammonia storage and handling system has been identified as the only process at the Ormond Beach Generating Station (Ormond Beach) facility, which triggers the CalARP RMP requirements. This system was determined to be covered by the CalARP Prevention Program 2 requirements.
On 31 March 2004, the amendment to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule (Risk Management Program), under the Clean Air Act, Section 112 (r) (7), was signed. The amendment:
Requires a correction to reportable information on chemical accidents be added to the RMP within 6 months of the date of the accident
Requires that changes to emergency contact information be corrected within 1 month
Removes the requirement to include a brief description of the offsite consequence analysis (OCA) in the RMPs Executive Summary
Adds three RMP data elements
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) also amended the RMP*Submit format to expand the list of possible causes for accidents to include uncontrolled chemical reactions. This amendment became effective on 9 April 2004 when it was published in the Federal Register (FR). In April 2008, EPA began work on the RMP*eSUBMIT software, which replaced RMP*Submit.
